page.title: 17Hedgerows.
page.content: Much of the farmland around Blisland is divided into small fields by hedges. The local hedges are built of two stone walls with earth between the stones and between the walls. A hedge may be two metres thick at ground level. A new hedge is soon colonised by plants and wildlife. Older hedges are inhabited by insects, small mammals, birds, wildflowers, bushes and even trees. The hedges were probably built with stone from a nearby quarry or with stones picked up to clear the field. Hedges have many values; they form boundaries between farms, keep livestock in _or out of_ a field, and provide animals with shelter and shade.
